mixSQP

Illustration of mix-SQP solver applied to a small data set, and a large one

Youngseok Kim and Peter Carbonetto

2018-10-02

In this vignette, we compare the runtime and accuracy of the mix-SQP algorithm against an interior-point (IP) solver implemented by the MOSEK commercial software (and called via the “KWDual” function in the REBayes package).

Environment set-up

We begin by loading the Rmosek and mixSQP packages.

library("Rmosek")
# Loading required package: Matrix
library("mixSQP")

Next, initialize the sequence of pseudorandom numbers.

set.seed(1)

Generate a small data set

Let’s begin with a smaller example with \(n = 50,000\) samples.

L <- simulatemixdata(5e4,10)$L
dim(L)
# [1] 50000    10

This call to simulatemixdata created an \(n \times k\) conditional likelihood matrix for a mixture of zero-centered normals, with \(k = 20\). Note that the rows of the likelihood matrix are normalized by default so that the maximum entry in each row is 1.

Fit mixture model

First, we fit the mixture model using the mix-SQP solver.

timing.sqp <- system.time(fit.sqp <- mixSQP(L))
cat(sprintf("Computation took %0.2f seconds.\n",timing.sqp["elapsed"]))
# Running mix-SQP 0.1-20 on 50000 x 10 matrix
# convergence tol. (SQP): 1.0e-08
# max. iter (SQP):        1000
# max. iter (active-set): 100
# zero threshold:         1.0e-08
# iter  objective   -min(g+1) #nnz #nqp #nls
#    1  7.51074e-01 +2.61e-01   10 
#    2  6.66166e-01 +4.51e+00    4   17    1
#    3  6.18728e-01 +2.13e+00    4    8    1
#    4  6.12130e-01 +9.29e-01    4    2    1
#    5  6.11262e-01 +3.69e-01    4    2    1
#    6  6.09558e-01 +1.69e-01    5    4    1
#    7  6.07030e-01 +5.93e-02    5    2    1
#    8  6.05031e-01 +1.11e-02    5    2    1
#    9  6.04453e-01 +5.03e-04    5    2    1
#   10  6.04423e-01 +1.08e-06    5    2    1
#   11  6.04423e-01 +4.67e-11    5    2    1
# Convergence criteria met; optimal solution found.
# Computation took 0.08 seconds.

Next, we fit the same mixture model using the IP solver.

timing.ip <- system.time(fit.ip <- mixKWDual(L))
cat(sprintf("Computation took %0.2f seconds.\n",timing.ip["elapsed"]))
# Computation took 0.76 seconds.

The runtime of the mix-SQP algorithm is about the same as the IP method, and the quality of the IP and SQP solutions is very similar.

cat(sprintf("Objective at SQP solution: %0.16f\n",fit.sqp$value,digits = 16))
cat(sprintf("Objective at IP solution:  %0.16f\n",fit.ip$value,digits = 16))
cat(sprintf("Difference in objectives:  %0.4e\n",fit.sqp$value - fit.ip$value))
# Objective at SQP solution: 0.6044234133387498
# Objective at IP solution:  0.6044234133023487
# Difference in objectives:  3.6401e-11

Comparison using a large data set

Session information

This next code chunk gives information about the computing environment used to generate the results contained in this vignette, including the version of R and the packages used.

sessionInfo()

Since we used Rmosek, it is also helpful to record the version of MOSEK that was used.

mosek_version()
# [1] "MOSEK 8.1.0.27"
